data.title: Newbie - Atom not appearing in the Start Menu
data.body:
I  recently downloaded and installed Atom.  It opened after it finished downloading.  However, I can't find it in the start menu, program list, and I can't make a shortcut to the desktop.  I can't even find a folder with a shortcut or program.  I just find the download file.

Is this normal?  Anyone have a solution?

data.title: Running apm in bash on Windows fails to find correct apm shell script
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Running `apm` in bash on Windows returns "No such file or directory.":

    $ apm
    /c/Users/jsmith/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.14.3/resources/cli/apm.sh: 
    line 3: /c/Users/jsmith/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.14.3/resources/cli/../app/apm/apm.sh: No such file or directory

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install atom > 1.14.0-beta.0
2. Open a bash terminal (e.g. Git Bash)
3. Run `apm`

**Expected behavior:** `apm` should execute successfully. E.g. `apm install` should work.

**Actual behavior:** `apm` is not found. It does not execute.

    $ apm
    /c/Users/jsmith/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.14.3/resources/cli/apm.sh: 
    line 3: /c/Users/jsmith/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.14.3/resources/cli/../app/apm/apm.sh: No such file or directory

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
$ atom --version

Atom    : 1.14.3
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
```
$ bash --version
GNU bash, version 4.3.42(5)-release (x86_64-pc-msys)
```

### Additional Information

It was [introduced in v1.14.0-beta0](https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/1efda55761c29fbe2e7afe8df608c0f192b6cda0#commitcomment-21023761). I have the fix. I will create a PR immediately following this.

data.title: Data loss scenarios with opening project with atom in empty state
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom 
        * There's a lot of issues filed for this already :) this is a issue to consolidate the root issues.  
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

This is to capture a few data loss scenarios with opening your project.  

There are 3 bugs that we can see so far that will cause data loss


### **Opening a Empty Document and try to `Open` the folder from context menu.**

  Repro:

  1. Open Atom, go to settings, check `Open Empty Editor On Start` and uncheck `Restore Previous Windows on Start` 
  2. Open a folder, add a few untitled documents or make changes to file and don't save anything.
  3. Close Atom
  4. Open Atom, you should get a blank editor
  5. Go to context menu and click `Open` (or cmd+o on mac) and open the folder from step 2.  

Expected: Restores Session
Actual: Unsaved session is lost.

### **Opening a Empty Document and trying to `Add a Project Folder` from context menu**

  Repro:

  1. Open Atom, go to settings, check `Open Empty Editor On Start` and uncheck `Restore Previous Windows on Start` 
  2. Open a folder, add a few untitled documents or make changes to file and don't save anything.
  3. Close Atom
  4. Open Atom, you should get a blank editor
  5. Go to context menu and click `Add a Project Folder...` (or cmd+shift+o on mac) and open the folder from step 2.  

Expected: Since there isn't any folder added yet, Atom should restore the session of that folder.
Actual: Unsaved session is lost. 

    
### **Open `atom .` when there is a empty atom editor open.**
Repro:
  1. Open Atom, go to settings, check `Open Empty Editor On Start` and uncheck `Restore Previous Windows on Start` 
  2. Open a folder, add a few untitled documents or make changes to file and don't save anything.
  3. Close Atom
  4. Open Atom, you should get a blank editor
  5. Go to terminal/powershell and go to the folder in step 2 and run `atom .` 

Expected: Restores Session
Actual: Unsaved session is lost. If no atom instance is running this works.


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100% of the time.  

### Versions
Atom 1.14.3

### Additional Information

This is causing a lot of various reports, but I think this is the underlying cause for most of them.  

/cc @lee-dohm @iolsen @ben3eee

### Description

When I try to enter numbers using the keyboard in an html file, atom does not allow input, but if it is any other file: css, js, text, I can enter numbers

### Steps to Reproduce

2. create .html file
3. try input number.

### Versions

npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.2

data.title: Copy Paste not working when editing XML files (Atom 1.14.3)
data.body:
This is to continue from a previous issue but was closed (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11881). 

I am now using Atom 1.14.3. 

Sorry, I got busy and did not use Atom for some time, lol. Now that I am back using it again, I tried testing this in Atom --safe mode and noticed something else. It appears to happen only in Mixed mode (see screenshot below). Mixed mode regarding CR / LF characters, you can see this on the file details on the bottom right in the screenshot.

You can also see when I copied the text from the Mixed mode XML file that it only copied the first character. I used the exact same example XML file as I originally attached to this issue.

And then I used a sample XML file using CRLF mode (Download from here: https://www.w3schools.com/xml/simple.xml). I was able to copy the text fine with this example, but not with the above example.

I wonder also, the encoding type set in the above XML is UTF-16, yet Atom reports it as UTF-8. Maybe it is having an issue reading the characters because of this?
It could also be the Mixed mode?

![atom safe mode test](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17824719/23263757/1d27f80e-f9d7-11e6-91cf-51377690f7cf.jpg)

data.title: Not responding when open minified JS file
data.body:
Hello, I am using Atom as web-development and it is really annoying that Atom freeze for a while when I open minified JS file.

The minified JS file is simply one really really long line of javascript code.

Any idea how this could be fixed ?
Perhaps disable the markup ?

data.title: Why atom doesnâ€™t have this feature yet?
data.body:
The idea is that you start working on your atom editor by logging into your account, all your working directories gets fetched from the remote server as repositories, you pick a repository or create new one, do your thing, and when you change your machine, you can start from where you left without worrying about pushing the code on git when its not ready to be commited yet.

Just like google chrome has this thing of picking from where you left when you change a device!

Wouldn't that be game changing!! is someone working on this? is there a package that does this already?

data.title: Atom closes without prompting to save
data.body:
Hello,
I am using Atom 1.14.3 in Mint-17 64-bit and the following scenario causes Atom to close without prompting to save the modified file.

Core setting is:
"Restore previous windows on start" -- UNCHECKED
"Open Empty editor on start" -- CHECKED

Scenario 1 - With just one Untitled tab (as expected)
1) Launch Atom editor from Menu
2) In the Untitled tab (document), type something to make it into a modified but DO NOT save the document
3) Close Atom and it will prompt you to save or to discard the Untitled document.

Scenario 2 - With one Untitled document + One unmodified file (The bug scenario)
1) Launch Atom editor from Menu
2) Open a document but do not modify it
3) If TreeView is shown, toggle it off
4) In the Untitled document, type something to modify it but do not save it. It does not matter how many "Untitled" documents are opened. 
5) Press Ctrl-Q or hit the X to close Atom. Atom does not prompt the user to save the Untitled document and simply discarding it and exit. OOPS! This is difference from Scenario 1.

I have been using an unmodified version of Atom other than to choose the themes from standard ones.

Rover

data.title: getPaths() does not return Project Path
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->
### Prerequisites
I did not do this in safe mode, since I don't know of anything that prints the project path without an addon of some kind.
I read through the FAQ's and Debugging guide.
This is for a package that I am helping to maintain.

### Description

The getPaths() method from the projects API is not functioning on Ubuntu 16.04. I am trying to extend an extension that does some things with project paths, and I've narrowed my troubles down to this method. I've hacked the extension that I'm working on so that when I run an atom command, it executes this line of bash script (This is actually a bit of coffee):
```"gnome-terminal -e \"bash -ic \'echo #{atom.project.getPaths().shift()} && read -s -n 1 line\'\""```
It's a little complicated, with a number of escape sequences, so I'll explain it here.
The ```gnome-terminal``` command runs all of the following using the -e option (this also works with xterm, although I've set my personal (and hacked) copy to gnome, since I prefer it).
```bash``` is run so that the terminal actually shows up, rather than just running without opening a gui at all. This corresponds to the read statement at the end (see below)
The ```echo``` bit is just the bit that I hacked so that it would print the string it's supposed to be cd'ing to instead of trying, failing, and closing. Eventually it will cd to that path, and then execute something in there, but that isn't particularly relevant.
```read``` (and all of it's args) is so that the terminal stays open so that you can see the output. 

This all works great, I can see the output of getPaths() just fine. The problem is the output itself: ```undefined```. Removing the .shift() property makes the method return nothing at all. I'm wondering if anyone else is having this problem (all platforms, I'm curious), and wondering why I'm having this issue (I am restarting atom every time I edit the file...).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a package that executes that bit of coffee when you run a certain atom command.
2. Run the command in atom. Ideally, you'll end up with a terminal with the output to your current project directory.

**Expected behavior:** I want it to spit out the project I'm currently working in.

**Actual behavior:** It prints ```undefined```

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time this is the case. I am led to believe that this is not the case on other platforms.

### Versions

```atom --version```:
Atom    : 1.14.2
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```apm --version```:
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.11+
git 2.7.4

Like I mentioned before, I'm running a release version of Ubuntu Linux 16.04 LTS 64 bit. Let me know if you need any more info.

data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages


### Description

Atom crashes when opening a folder containing a git sparse checkout.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a sparse checkout of a git repo.
  - `mkdir thisWillCrashAtom`
  - `cd thisWillCrashAtom`
  - `git init`
  - `git config core.sparseCheckout true`
  - `git remote add -f origin git://...`
  - `echo someRepoPath/* > .git/info/sparse-checkout`
  - `git checkout master`
2. Open the `thisWillCrashAtom` directory with atom

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens without crashing.

**Actual behavior:** Atom crashes.

**Reproduces how often:** Always.

### Versions

Windows 64-bit (Windows 7 and Windows 10)

Atom    : 1.14.3
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 ia32
python 3.5.2
git 1.9.4.msysgit.1
visual studio 2012

data.title: Large file under git takes a long time to edit and save
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Saving and making edits on large file is extremely slow.  
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Add the following file to a git repo.
https://expirebox.com/download/9aa6293a45a458215b2bbc589a97dad7.html
2. Open the file on atom in safe mode.  `atom --safe .`
3. Make Edits (Atom becomes unresponsive for a few seconds)
4. Save(Atom becomes so unresponsive that a dialog pops up asking if you want to keep waiting.  
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/23180837/9bffe576-f827-11e6-8c0f-c8d06913edbd.png)

**Expected behavior:** Atom saves 

**Actual behavior:** Atom is really really slow and even becomes unresponsive.  

**Reproduces how often:** 100%
### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

If the file is not in a git repo this works pretty well and is reasonably fast, but doesn't work that well when it's in a git repo.

data.title: Auto identation issue caused by sql query in php script
data.body:
Hi,
I noticed a little bug with auto identation.

Here is two codes after auto identation :
![bug_atom_ident](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7705276/23130632/7c7ffe8e-f787-11e6-8cb7-346144b94124.png)

As you can see, the closing ")' of the sql subquery seems to disturb the auto identation.

It only works if the closing ")" is on a new line, and if the string is not cutted, for exemple, this code doesn't work 

`public function withSql() {`
`    $query = "SELECT * FROm test WHERE test IN (`
`    test";`
`    $query .= ")";`
`}`

data.title: Raster text cursor doesn't scale and doesn't look native
data.body:
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

By default, Atom uses a base64 encoded image as the text cursor in the atom-text-editor component. There are some problems with this:

- It's not the native text cursror - looks out of place
- It doesn't scale well - the first image below is the default cursor, with macOS cursor scaling enabled. The second shows the native OS text cursor (pixellated..). The native cursror was scaled correctly as a vector but the screenshot tool for some reason renders it at the normal 1x size (just imagine it scaled properly :))

![cursor-img](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4211302/23124134/4f4b3998-f763-11e6-9534-90431208c23e.png)

![cursor-reg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4211302/23124137/55d5812e-f763-11e6-9f83-e5fcbe1fa98d.png)

Fix is to use something similar to this: 

```css
atom-text-editor.editor .scroll-view {
    cursor: text;
}
```

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Hover over a text field

**Expected behavior:** Cursor should be native text cursor, should scale with accessibility settings

**Actual behavior:** Cursor is a custom raster image - therefore becomes pixellated when scaled

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```fish
> atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.15.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.
```

macOS sierra 10.12.3

data.title: Don't let run atom as root
data.body:
In particular for experienced users is [pretty known](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10566#issuecomment-278616243) they shouldn't run atom as root, not only for problems this make on .atom folder but also because of security issues. [In this post Martin GrÃ¤ÃŸlin](https://blog.martin-graesslin.com/blog/2017/02/editing-files-as-root/) (Kate and Kwrite developer) say:

> Today I pushed a change for Kate and KWrite which does no longer allow to be run as root. Instead it educates the user about how to do the same with sudoedit.

Probably Atom should do the same.

data.title: Consistent deprecation message
data.body:
Hi all,

I have a consistent deprecation message from atom but not sure where to fix it:

```
atom core (1 deprecation)
Assigning editor 8's height explicitly via position: 'absolute' and an assigned top and bottom implicitly assigns the autoHeight property to false on the editor. This behavior is deprecated and will not be supported in the future. Please explicitly assign autoHeight on this editor.
TextEditorComponent.measureDimensions - C:\MyPrograms\AtomPortable\App\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor-component.js:1012:20
TextEditorComponent.becameVisible - C:\MyPrograms\AtomPortable\App\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor-component.js:295:12
TextEditorComponent.checkForVisibilityChange - C:\MyPrograms\AtomPortable\App\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor-component.js:994:16
atom-text-editor.attachedCallback - C:\MyPrograms\AtomPortable\App\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor-element.js:87:22
atom-pane.activeItemChanged - C:\MyPrograms\AtomPortable\App\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\pane-element.js:138:24
Function.module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch - C:\MyPrograms\AtomPortable\App\Atom\resources\app.asar\node_modules\event-kit\lib\emitter.js:25:14
```

I use atom portable. Everytime I update, I used to delete the old "Atom" folder and extract the new contents into relevant folder.

Thank you.
